item.title: Bar charts in fisheries data visualization using python
item.description:
This example is a python version of a post titled "bar charts in visualizing fisheries data with R". The purpose of doing this post is that it would be interesting to develop my skills in more than one language. Therefore, if you don't mind, please look at this R version to get the conceptional idea of plotting before jumping into the python syntax. So far, I feel that what I can do with R can also do with python, but the python code requires some switching language process. 


# importing useful libraries
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

Data exploration



# importing data
age_at_length = pd.read_csv("age_length_data.csv")
catch_at_length = pd.read_csv("catch_length.csv")
# data exploration
print(type(age_at_length))
print(age_at_length.shape)
print(age_at_length.dtypes)

print(type(catch_at_length))
print(catch_at_length.shape)
print(catch_at_length.dtypes)


<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
(65, 13)
length    int64
age.3     int64
age.4     int64
age.5     int64
age.6     int64
age.7     int64
age.8     int64
age.9     int64
age.10    int64
age.11    int64
age.12    int64
age.13    int64
age.14    int64
dtype: object
<class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
(65, 2)
Length    int64
Count     int64
dtype: object

Visualization of catch at length



plt.bar(catch_at_length.Length,catch_at_length.Count, color = "lightblue")
plt.xlabel("length")
plt.ylabel("Number of fish")
plt.show()

Figure 1. Barplot of Catch at length

Visualization of catch at age



age_at_length_select = age_at_length.drop(["length"], axis=1)
age_at_length["total"] = age_at_length_select.sum(axis=1)
age_at_length_proportion = age_at_length_select.div(age_at_length.total, axis = 0)
catch_at_age = age_at_length_proportion.mul(catch_at_length.Count, axis = 0)
catch_at_age_sum = catch_at_age.sum(axis = 0)


plt.bar(pd.Series(np.arange(3,15,1)),catch_at_age_sum, color = "lightblue")
plt.xlabel("Age")
plt.ylabel("Number of fish")
plt.show()

Figure 2. Bar plot of catch at age

Visualization of the distribution of age at length



age_at_length_plot = age_at_length_proportion.plot(kind="bar", stacked = True, width = .8)
age_at_length_plot.set_xticklabels(np.arange(53,118,1), rotation = 0)
age_at_length_plot.xaxis.set_major_locator(plt.MaxNLocator(10))
plt.legend(bbox_to_anchor = (1.25,1), loc = "upper right")
plt.xlabel("Length")
plt.ylabel("Frequency")
plt.show()

Figure 3. Bar plot of age at length distribution 

catch_at_length_ts = pd.read_csv("catch.at.length.ts1.csv")
catch_at_length_ts_select = catch_at_length_ts.drop(["length"], axis = 1)


S1 = {}
S2 = {}
S3 = {}
S4 = {}

X = age_at_length_proportion
Y = catch_at_length_ts_select

for i in range(0, len(Y.columns)):
    S1[i] = Y[Y.columns[i]]
    S2[i] = X.mul(S1[i], axis = 0)
    S3[i] = S2[i].apply(np.sum, axis = 0)
    S4[i] = S3[i].div(S3[i].sum(axis = 0))

col_name2 = np.arange(1959,2017,1)
catch_at_age = pd.DataFrame(S4)
catch_at_age = catch_at_age.set_axis(col_name2, axis = 1, inplace = False)
catch_at_age_t = catch_at_age.T

Visualization of the distribution of catch at age over time



catch_at_age_plot = catch_at_age_t.plot(kind = "bar", stacked = True, width = .8)
catch_at_age_plot.set_xticklabels(np.arange(1959,2017,1), rotation = 0)
catch_at_age_plot.xaxis.set_major_locator(plt.MaxNLocator(12))
plt.legend(bbox_to_anchor = (1.25,1), loc = "upper right")
plt.xlabel("Year")
plt.ylabel("Frequency")
plt.show()

Figure 4. Bar plot of catch at age over time

  2. catch at length
  3. catch at length for multiple years

item.title: Bar charts in fisheries data visualization using R
item.description:
Data exploration

First thing first, it is usually required to know the data before working on it. There are many different ways to explore a data set using R. In this example, I just provide some functions that I frequently use for data exploration at work. Also, I assume that you already have some foundational knowledge about R programming. Furthermore, if you have some background in fisheries, this post would make a lot of sense. 

# importing data
age.at.length <- read.csv("age_length_data.csv")
catch.at.length <- read.csv("catch_length.csv")
# data exploration
class(age.at.length)
## [1] "data.frame"
dim(age.at.length) 
## [1] 65 13
sapply(age.at.length, class)
##    length     age.3     age.4     age.5     age.6     age.7     age.8     age.9
## "integer" "integer" "integer" "integer" "integer" "integer" "integer" "integer"
##    age.10    age.11    age.12    age.13    age.14
## "integer" "integer" "integer" "integer" "integer"

So far, I know that age.at.length contains the information of fish age and length and is a data frame consisting of 65 rows and 14 columns. Furthermore, the function sapply() tells me that all the values are integers. 

class(catch.at.length)
## [1] "data.frame"
dim(catch.at.length) 
## [1] 65  2
sapply(catch.at.length, class)
##    Length     Count
## "integer" "integer"

The same technique is applied to explore the data of catch.at.length. It is a data frame of two variables: fish length and count (i.e., the number of fish) consisting of 65 records.

Visualization of catch at length

At this point, I would be curious to see how many fish are measured at a particular length. For this purpose, a bar plot can be generated using an R-base function. It is noted that ggplot2 or some other packages can do this type of plotting very well, but I would prefer to use simple techniques where possible. 

barplot(catch.at.length$Count,names=catch.at.length$Length,
        xlab = "Length", ylab = "Number of fish",
        col = "lightblue", border = NA)
Figure 1. Barplot of Catch at length

Visualization of catch at age

At this stage, measurements of length at age and catch at length are available. I would be curious to see how many fish are caught at particular ages. For this purpose, catch at age data is required. The computation of generating catch at age is presented as follows.

  1. Compute the proportion of age at length
  2. Catch at age = proportion of age at length * catch at length
  3. Generate a bar plot for the catch at age

R code for computing catch at age is shown bellow. 

library(dplyr)
age.at.length <- age.at.length %>% mutate(total=apply(age.at.length[,-1],1,sum)) # create a new column for the total of catch
age.at.length.in.proportion <- age.at.length[,c(2:14)]/age.at.length$total # compute the proportion of age at length
catch.at.age <- age.at.length.in.proportion*catch.at.length$Count # compute catch at age
catch.at.age <- apply(catch.at.age[,-13],2,sum, na.rm = T) # compute the total of catch for each age
# view the catch at age data
catch.at.age
##  age.3  age.4  age.5  age.6  age.7  age.8  age.9 age.10 age.11 age.12 age.13
## 14.000 13.000 18.000 17.000 17.000 12.000 15.000 20.375 20.500 16.125 19.000
## age.14
## 18.000

It is now simple to generate a bar chart for catch at age using an R-base code. 

barplot(catch.at.age,names=c(3:14),
        xlab = "Age", ylab = "Number of fish",
        col = "lightblue", border = NA)
Figure 2. Bar plot of catch at age

Visualization of the distribution of age at length

At this point, I am aware that there are some fish of the same age, but their lengths are varied; also, some other fish having the same measurement of length, but their ages are different. How would the data be visualized to get a better insight into it? The code is shown below. 

age.at.length.in.proportion.t <- t(age.at.length.in.proportion)
colnames(age.at.length.in.proportion.t) <- catch.at.length$Length
row.names(age.at.length.in.proportion.t) <- c(3:15)

library(RColorBrewer)
options(warn = -1)
col1 <- brewer.pal(nrow(age.at.length.in.proportion.t), "Paired")
barplot(age.at.length.in.proportion.t[-13,], col = col1, xlim = c(0, 88),
        xlab = "Length (unit)", ylab = "Frequency", border = NA)
legend1 <- legend("topright",legend = c(3:14), title = "Age", fill = col1, box.col = "white")
Figure 3. Bar plot of age at length distribution


As shown in figure 3, it is clear that fish of length > 116 cm is 14 years old. At the ages of 3, 4, and 5, their lengths distribute in three ranges (53-57, 65-69, and 73-79 cm), respectively. In contrast, the other age classes consist of fish with diverse length measurements.

Visualization of the distribution of catch at age over time

The example presented in figure 2 is the distribution of catch at age in one year. If the catch at length is recorded for many years by commercial fishers, also length at age is available from some ageing work. It would be interesting to see how the distribution of catch at age changes over time. A new data set called âcatch.at.length.ts1.csvâ is used for this example. 

# importing the data
catch.at.length.ts <- read.csv("catch.at.length.ts1.csv")
colnames(catch.at.length.ts) <- c("length",array(1959:2016)) # re-name columns

In figure 2 example, catch at age was computed for one year only; however, this example contains a series of years from 1959 to 2017. Therefore, the use of a for loop would make the calculation for multiple years efficient. The code is presented below. 

X <- age.at.length.in.proportion[,-13]
Y <- catch.at.length.ts[,-1]

S1 <- list()
S2 <- list()
S3 <- list()

for (i in 1:ncol(Y)) {
  S1[i] <- subset(Y, select = c(i))
  S2[[i]] <- X * S1[[i]]
  S3[[i]] <- apply(S2[[i]],2,sum,na.rm=T)
}

catch.at.age.ts <- as.data.frame(do.call(cbind,S3))
colnames(catch.at.age.ts) <- c(1959:2016)
row.names(catch.at.age.ts) <- c(3:14)

M <- as.matrix(catch.at.age.ts)
M <- M%*%diag(1/apply(M,2,sum))
colnames(M) <- c(1959:2016)

Once the required data is ready, it will be simple to plot a bar chart to examine the distribution of catch at age over multiple years. 

# Proportion at age
barplot(M, col = col1, xlim = c(0, 80),
        xlab = "Year", ylab = "Frequency", border = NA)
legend1 <- legend("topright",legend = c(3:14), title = "Age", fill = col1, box.col = "white")
Figure 4. Bar plot of catch at age over time


This is the end of the first post in fisheries data visualization using R. The code presented here is just one of many ways to do the visualization. I hope you enjoy it. Please feel free to hit me up with your comments or questions.

Data for this post:

  1. age at length
  2. catch at length
  3. catch at length for multiple years

item.title: Daily ageing for Gambusia fish
item.description:
Figure 1. An illustration of Gambusia holbrooki . Drawing by S. Laurie-Bourque.

The introduction and establishment of non-indigenous species are severe issues corresponding with environmental and economic losses, particularly in freshwater habitats. The pest fish, Gambusia holbrooki , is now a prioritized target of eradication from Tasmania. However, there is a limited quantitative analysis of their population dynamics due to little information on fish ageing.

This study centred on the use of otoliths (sagittae and lapilli) to determine daily age for the species. Of 394 fish collected from March to June 2018, 193 (~50%) were successfully aged. Sample preparation was successful for lapilli removed from fish, while preparation of sagittae succeeded for the full range of sampled fish (7mm â¤ TL â¤41 mm). Growth increments appeared as a combination of an opaque and a translucent band in polished otoliths. Ageing reared fish found that increment counts rarely equalled but proportionally correlated to known age. Therefore, estimates of age for wild fish were computed using numbers of increments counted from reading sagittae.

Figure 2. Growth increments as observed in a polished sagitta of a wild fish (TL=19 mm, estimated age=38 days post birth). Scale bar = 20 Âµm.

A multi-model approach was applied to describe the growth of G. holbrooki versus daily time-series data. Akaikeâs information criteria revealed that the power equation outperformed the other candidate models in processing reared fish (Wi = 98% and 59% for females and males respectively) and female wild fish data (Wi = 35%). Von Bertalanffy and logistic equations were best fitted to male fish in the wild (Wi = 27%). Using Pauly's estimator, estimates of the natural mortality rate were 0.035 day-1 and 0.16 day-1 for wild females and males.

It was evident that the birth rate was closely correlated with mean temperature changes in Tasmania with peak reproduction in January 2018. Growth rate significantly differed among cohorts birthed at different times. On average, the means of growth rate estimated for the young cohort (0.28 mm/day) was much greater than that of the overâwinter cohort (0.12 mm/day).

The wild sample ranged from fish of TL=13 mm to 63 mm with the mode of length-frequency from 22â26mm. Mature females dominated the population (2.3 female:1 male) and were typically greater than mature males in total length and total weight.

This study, for the first time, provided evidence of using otoliths (sagittae and lapilli) in determining the daily age of G. holbrooki with the opportunity of quantitively examining biological characteristics and the dynamics of a population in Tasmania, Australia; which can be used to inform pest control and eradication programs both locally and globally.

  • Honour thesis
  • Final presentation
